text: Out of the darkness, the screeching moan of an arriving train. A dark swarm of bodies file out of the LEXINGTON a 59TH ST STATION. We descend upon the crowd, singling out young man in coat and hat, JACK TAFT, late 20s, who weave through the line of COMMUTERS, some opening umbrellas to patchy skies. JACK buys an evening paper at a newsstand a makes his way across 59th. EXT./INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. NIGHT. JACK enters the hotel and we follow him as he walks throu the lobby to the bar. JACK easily finds a stool, nods to BARTENDER and tosses him the newspaper. The BARTENDER poi to a bottle of Dewars and JACK gives him a thumbs up. He scans the cocktail lounge adjacent to the bar - not much activity in there, either: a FEW TABLES OF BUSINESSMEN getting drunk, an ELDERLY COUPLE, TWO WOMEN tucked away i corner table. JACK checks his watch and the BARTENDER set down his drink.
Not much going on for a Friday.
It’s early yet. JACK downs his scotch, slides his empty glass over to the BARTENDER, taps out a rhythm along the edge of the bar.

Say Cal, make it a double, would you? And one for yourself. I gotta make a call. JACK gets up. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. NIGHT. JACK makes his way through the lounge on his way to a telephone booth. He takes another look at the TWO WOMEN tucked away in the corner, deep in conversation, and thin he recognizes one of them. He begins approaching them.
Therese? Is that you? THERESE, the younger of the women, turns to look at JACK.
What do you know! (he starts over) I'm saying to myself, I know that girl. It seems to take her a split second to react, to stand a greet JACK with a short hug.
Jack.
Gee it’s great to see you, Therese. It’s been, well, months.

Months. The OTHER WOMAN at the table lights a cigarette. THERESE glances at her, and they hold a brief, tense look before THERESE remembers her manners. THERESE (CONT’D) Jack, this is Carol Aird. JACK holds out his hand. CAROL shakes it.
Pleased to meet you.
Likewise. CAROL retreats back to her own thoughts, smokes.
Hey, Ted Gray’s meeting me here and a bunch of us are heading down to Phil’s party. You’re going aren’t you?
Well - yes. I just planned to get there a little...(looking to Carol)
You should go ahead.
You coming along?
No, no. (to THERESE) I should make a few calls before dinner, anyway. I should really run.
You sure?
Of course.
(to JACK) Well... it would be great to catch a ride. CAROL takes a step towards THERESE, but no more.
You two have a wonderful night. Nice meeting you, Jack.
Nice meeting you. And she’s gone. THERESE doesn’t move, doesn’t turn around watch CAROL leave.
Alright, well let me go make sure the loaf is on his way. Back ina flash. JACK takes off. A beat before THERESE turns and scans the and beyond for CAROL. But she’s gone.

BRIEF SHOTS (INT. TOY DEPARTMENT - FRANKENBERG’S) A toy train whizzes by the faces of miniature pedestrians a department store display. CAROL AIRD, seen from a dista in winter coat, stands watching. MORNI An alarm blares over the sleeping face of THERESE BELIVET huddled under covers. THERESE doesn’t stir though the ala continues. Finally, THERESE, in one skilled manoeuver, pu herself up and out of bed, still cocooned within the blankets. She finds the alarm clock and shuts it off. She looks at the alarm clock. It reads 7.00 A.M. THERESE moves through her morning rituals: she throws ope her window shades, moves on to a small gas stove, strikes match and lights the stove to take the chill off, moves o the kitchen sink set in one corner of the room, which dou as a partial home darkroom - developer and fixer trays stacked to the side of the sink, an Argus C3 camera from late 1930s set on a shelf above the sink, along with a collection of red or amber light bulbs and photo paper. The room is sparsely furnished, and much of the wall spac taken up with THERESE’S B&W photos, mostly NY CITY STREET SCENES and URBAN LANDSCAPES. THERESE is brushing her teet when the doorbell rings. Once. Twice. Three times. She sh her blankets and goes to the window, opens it, leans out. EXT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. CONTINUOUS. THERESE’S boyfriend, RICHARD SEMCO, looks up at her from street, striding his bicycle. He’s well-bundled in scarf hat.
I like your scribbles. RICHARD looks around to the street behind him covered in children’s chalk scribblings.
Yeah - I’ve been busy! (grinning at her): I don’t know how you look a million bucks first thing in the morning.
I won't be a minute. EXT. CENTRAL PARK. NY CITY. MORNING. RICHARD rides THERESE to work through the park. She sits her arms wrapped around his hips while he stands pumping at the pedals.
So I got the schedules. In the mail. You listening to me?
I’m listening! You got the schedules.
And there are two sailings to France in June, one in July.
Wow.
So whaddya think?
I think... I think it’s so cold I can’t think straight.

Oh yeah? Well let’s get you warmed up. RICHARD accelerates. THERESE laughs, holds on tighter. RICHARD begins to sing: “I love Paris in the... summer-ti as they speed away. EXT. FRANKENBERG’S DEPARTMENT STORE. MORNING. Outside the employee’s entrance, RICHARD and THERESE stan a longish line of MOSTLY YOUNG STAFF waiting to begin the work day. Everyone looks exactly the same: a lot cold, a little Soviet-factory-worker glum.

Anyway she wants to make it for you so there’s no use fighting it, once she gets an idea in her head... She's just going crazy with no girls in the family but Esther- A SECURITY GUARD has opened the door and the line has beg to move. Compliments of the season from the management. THERESE takes her cap, doesn’t put it on, moves inside.

I gotta open the floor. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE CAFETERIA. MORNING. From a table in the corner, THERESE sips at a cup of coff and watches a sea of Santa-capped and uniform-smocked STA move wordlessly along the breakfast line, accepting gooey eggs and cups of coffee. THERESE looks down at a Frankenberg’s employee handbook. We glimpse bits and piec of information: ...2 weeks vacation after 5 years, 4 week vacation after 15 years... full pension, benefits...” She turns a page: “Are YOU Frankenberg Material?” It’s too depressing to take in. THERESE slips the handboo back into her purse and removes a copy of Joyce’s “Portra of the Artist as a Young Man.” But just as she settles in ROBERTA WALLS, an officious supervisor in bright red harlequin glasses, swoops by THERESE planting a Santa cap firmly onto her head.

You're needed upstairs, Miss Belivet. Make it snappy. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL STOCK ROOM. MORNING. THERESE, surrounded by rows of identical Christmas dolls, counts stock. THERESE watches a very middle-aged, wheezin employee, RUBY ROBICHEK, struggle with carrying seven or eight large boxes across the stock room floor. RUBY can’t in front of her, and as she attempts to peer around the e of the boxes, most of the boxes tumble out of RUBY’S arms onto the floor. THERESE quickly determines she’s the only help on the fl and goes to assist RUBY, who has great difficulty in knee to pick up the boxes.
(kneels to help RUBY) Please- let me help. RUBY is grateful to avoid kneeling, and places each box THERESE hands to her on the display counter.
Thanks an awful lot, honey. I keep telling them upstairs we need more stock boys come the holidays, but they haven't listened in 18 years.
You’ve been here 18 years?
Oh, sure. And when you're here long enough, you’1l get inventive with juggling boxes, like me.
I’m just a temporary. For the holiday.

(shrugs) I said that once. INT. FRANKENBERG'S. TOY DEPARTMENT. MORNING. Just before opening: a surreal calm and silence. THERESE, Santa cap, and makeshift bandage, stands beside an elabor model train set. She flips a switch and the train set com to life - the tiny lights, the tinny whir of the engine a the train chugs its way along the track. A LOUD BUZZER sounds. Behind THERESE, we can see the analogue lift indicator start to move: 5th floor, 4th floor, 3rd floor. as the lift descends to accept its first load of daily customers and a voice bellows from the intercom:

Good morning, Happy Holidays and welcome, shoppers, to Frankenberg’s. Be sure to take advantage of our Congratulations Ike and Mamie Inaugural Early Bird special in our Beds and Bedding Department on the second floor. (MORE )

And on your way there, you won’t want to miss our brand new General Electric television and stereophonic display on the first floor, just past the haberdashery. Behind THERESE, the lift doors open and all at once THERE is swallowed up by the rush of MANAGERS, STAFF and CUSTOM INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DEPARTMENT. LATER THERESE sits behind a display case full of dolls. She tri to make herself invisible while she surreptitiously reads book. The department is full of MOTHERS buying Christmas gifts for their children. THERESE’S reading is interrupte a SHARP WAILING. She looks up to see a TODDLER throwing a tantrum and an EMBARRASSED MOM trying to get the situatio under control. Just then, ROBERTA WALLS bustles through t department, sees THERESE, points to THERESE’S head - wher the Santa cap? ROBERTA WALLS seems to say without saying THERESE hurriedly stashes her book into her handbag and p out the cap. She tries to hide the bloodstains. ROBERTA W nods to THERESE and moves on. THERESE settles back down, bored. A CUSTOMER looks expectantly to THERESE; THERESE pretends she doesn’t see CUSTOMER and ducks down to her handbag to retrieve her bo She looks up above the desk to see where the CUSTOMER wen and instead spies a glance of another woman - a woman who green silk scarf tied loosely around her neck and head catches THERESE’S attention. CAROL stands up, turns around towards the doll department, smil as if asking for help. THERESE meets CAROL’S eyes for a strange split second - u the EMBARRASSED MOM and the screaming TODDLER appear in f of THERESE, blocking her view of anything else.
Where’s the ladies room, honey?

To the left, past men’s shoes, then right at the tie racks. EMBARRASSED MOM nods her thanks and hoists TODDLER away. THERESE looks for CAROL, but she’s no longer there. The t set is back on, and being admired by several sets of FATH and SONS.  INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DEPARTMENT. MOMENTS LATER Behind and below the desk, THERESE contemplates sneaking read of her book, but decides against it. I’m looking for a doll. She’s about- (she gestures)- this high and this wide and... (rethinking): Let's begin again, shall we? As CAROL steps away from the desk a moment to rummage thr her purse, THERESE can’t stop staring - at her well-tailo suit, her blonde hair, her green silk scarf. CAROL produc crumpled slip of paper, steps back up to the desk, gives THERESE a big smile as she hands it to her.
I wonder if you might help me find this doll for my daughter. THERESE reads the slip of paper.
Bright Betsy. She cries.
Oh she does?
And wets herself. But we’re out of stock.
I’ve left it too long. She begins to rummage through her purse.
We have plenty of other dolls. All kinds, umm... THERESE, suddenly tongue-tied, turns toward the doll disp which CAROL turns to as well.
Right. What was your favorite doll when you were four? Do you remember?
Me? I never... Not many, to be honest.  10 CAROL raises a cigarette to her lips, begins to light it, THERESE interrupts. THERESE (CONT’D) Sorry. No smoking on the sales floor.
Oh, of all the - forgive me. (beat) Shopping makes me nervous.
That's okay. Working here makes me nervous. CAROL laughs, appreciating THERESE’S commiseration.
You're very kind. Their eyes meet for a moment, before CAROL rummages insid her purse again. She produces a billfold, opens it, shows to THERESE. It’s a photo of RINDY, CAROL’S 4-YEAR-OLD DAUGHTER.
She looks like you. Around the mouth. The eyes.
(glancing at THERESE) You think so? THERESE looks up, clocks CAROL watching her, looks down. bit of an awkward moment that CAROL rescues:
So what did you want? When you were that age?
(no hesitation) A train set.
Really. That’s a surprise. (beat) Do you know much about train sets?

I do actually. And there’s a new model, just in last week. Hand- built with hand-painted cars - it’s a limited edition of five thousand, with the most sophisticated electric switching system - it’s quite...  11 THERESE checks her own enthusiasm, noticing CAROL’S eyes her. THERESE (CONT ’D) You may have seen it. Over by the elevators? Just there- THERESE points towards the train set and CAROL turns to l mulling it over. THERESE watches her every move.
(turns back to THERESE) Do you ship?
Special delivery. Or courier. (beat) You'll have it in two, three days. Two days. We’ll even assemble it.
Well. That’s... that. Sold. They stand there, nodding at each other for a moment.
Shall I pay now?

Oh - yes, of course. THERESE begins writing out a sales slip, then slides it o to CAROL with a pen, glancing up at her. CAROL snaps out brief moment of thought, a distance. THERESE (CONT’D) We'll need your account details, your shipping address.

Of course. (she begins writing) I love Christmas. At least I love the preparation. Wrapping gifts, all that. And then... you somehow wind up overcooking the turkey anyway. She finishes, flashing a bright smile. THERESE doesn’t qu follow her, but she doesn’t want CAROL to stop talking. CAROL (CONT’D) Done. CAROL hands the pen and sales slip back to THERESE. CAROL (CONT’D) Where’d you learn so much about train sets, anyway?  12
I - read... Too much, probably.
It's refreshing. Thank you. (beat) And Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas. CAROL walks away. THERESE watches her, takes her all in - manner, her style, her walk. CAROL turns back for a momen and points to THERESE’S cap.

I like your hat. THERESE watches her go off past the train set and elevato For a moment she watches as the empty spaces left behind filled by shoppers and staff. She cranes her neck for one last look but it’s no good. She’s gone. THERESE sighs. Sh looks down at the doll desk and sees that CAROL has left gloves behind.

Move over. Nobody else can see the screen.

My kid brother, the movie jerk. DANNIE, embarrassed, moves slightly away from the glass. he still watches, still jots notes. THERESE watches him. INT. GREENWICH VILLAGE BAR. NIGHT. RICHARD and PHIL have been drinking quite a bit. A row of empty beer bottles is lined up on the table in front of t DANNIE sips at a glass of Coca-Cola. THERESE nurses a gla of wine.
I'm strictly a beer man. Everything else makes me want to vomit.
Wine makes me feel naughty. In a good way.
Is there any other way to feel naughty?
I drink to forget I gotta get up for work in the morning.
That’s your problem, Semco. You really ought to drink because you remember you have a job. Employment’s a curse.
You have a job, Phil.
You call that a job? I call it an illusion.
You get paid. Is money an illusion?
My kid brother, the jerk philosopher.
(to Dannie) Where do you work?  15
(mock respect) Didn’t you know - Dannie works at the New York Times. RICHARD and PHIL feign awe.
(she’s impressed) No kidding.

(he shrugs) It’s a job. (to THERESE) What I want to do is write. That’s why I watch movies.
(rolling his eyes) Everybody's a writer.... DANNIE tries to blend into the woodwork. He catches THERE eye. She smiles at him. He appreciates it.
Say, Therese - before I get too drunk to remember.... PHIL digs into a large messenger bag, pulls out a camera, old Kodak, and hands it to THERESE.
You did it? It’s fixed?
He said it was a cinch. No sweat.
Thank you, Phil! I was missing it!
So, you take pictures?
Well.
She's more excited by some chintzy camera than she is about sailing with me to Europe!
Women!  16

You said it, pal! RICHARD and PHIL laugh, toast, drink. THERESE isn’t amuse DANNIE clocks this. EXT. THIRD AVENUE. NIGHT. THERESE walks with DANNIE. RICHARD and PHIL, now very dru and rowdy, walk slightly ahead of them, with RICHARD guid his bicycle unsteadily along the pavement.

What you oughta do is hit Spain... whatsitcalled - Pamplona. Catch a bullfight! Up ahead a couple is approaching who everyone knows: JACK TAFT and his girlfriend, DOROTHY. The men all speak to ea other as DOROTHY speaks to THERESE.

Richard, watch out, you’re-! But she’s too late to save RICHARD from backing into a lamppost. He falls down, the bicycle topples down on top him. PHIL attempts to help but tumbles onto RICHARD, and both dissolve into a fit of drunken laughter.

Let me.

Like that? RICHARD lets go of THERESE’S hand and leans back, closes eyes. He lets out a low moan.  18 THERESE watches RICHARD intently the whole time, as if sh more an observer than a full participant. RICHARD’S breat rapidly quickens.

Give her my best. I’ve always liked Jeanette. CAROL checks RINDY’S drawing, slides another color over t her. As she does, HARGE slides a hand over CAROL'S.

LATE AFTERNO THERESE at her desk is being exhausted by a PICKY FEMALE CUSTOMER. A score of open doll boxes and dolls are sprawl across the desk.

Belivet? Miss Belivet? THERESE looks up. ROBERTA WALLS stands at a desk nearby, crooking a finger at THERESE and holding a telephone rece up. ROBERTA WALLS (CONT’D) Over here please. Now? She snaps her fingers for another SALES CLERK to take ove from THERESE.

(to CUSTOMER) Sorry - I’m - excuse me. THERESE hurries over to ROBERTA WALLS as the SALES CLERK takes over the PICKY FEMALE CUSTOMER. ROBERTA WALLS hands receiver to THERESE and shoots her a withering look. THER takes the phone. THERESE (CONT’D) Hello?
Is this employee 645-A, Tereeza Belivet?
Yes.  23

We're patching you though, ma‘am. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATE AFTERNOON. CAROL cooks dinner as she makes her call, which helps her combat some of her residual shyness. A radio is tuned in some BIG BAND MUSIC.
So it was you. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DESK. LATE AFTERNOON. THERESE on the phone. WALLS, stony-faced and staring.
Oh - hello. Mrs. Aird? Did you - receive the train set alright? INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATE AFTERNOON.
I did. And the gloves. Thank you so much. You’re a star for sending them. I just called to say - thank you, really.
Of course. CAROL picks up a saucepan lid but it’s too hot and she dr it. It clatters on the floor.

Oh, shit - sorry. What I mean to say - Do you get a lunch hour there? - Let me take you to lunch. It’s the least I can do. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DESK. LATE AFTERNOON. THERESE blinks. Hard. She holds a long breath before replying, mindful of ROBERTA WALLS attuned to her every w

I - well. Yes, of course. But you really don’t- (pause) Tomorrow? (pause) No, I don’t know it. Hold on. (sheepishly to ROBERTA) I'm sorry. Can I borrow a paper and a pencil?  24 ROBERTA WALLS isn’t happy as she slides a paper and penci over to THERESE. THERESE quickly scribbles down an addres INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY. THERESE stands at the front of a small midtown restaurant with white tablecloths and wooden rafters. She glances up the clock which reads 1:12 and checks it against her wristwatch. She glances out the window. There, through beveled glass, she spots CAROL hurrying across the street

head_text.subj: INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY. MOMENTS LATER

text: CAROL and THERESE are seated at a quiet table. CAROL is removing her hat, glancing at her menu as a WAITER hovers THERESE sits transfixed, her eyes quick and alert, taking everything about CAROL from the way a delicate gold brace falls against her wrist as she peruses her menu to the wa CAROL'S fingers grip her water glass.

I’m so sorry to keep you waiting. (to the WAITER) I’1l have the creamed spinach over poached eggs. And a dry martini. With an olive. CAROL and the WAITER look to THERESE, who realizes she ha even opened her menu. A beat, then:
I‘1l have the same.
The meal or the drink?
Uhh - All of it. Thank you. The WAITER nods, starting off, as CAROL clocks THERESE’S uncertainty. THERESE not wanting to stare at CAROL, now p up her menu and thumbs through it.

Cigarette? CAROL offers THERESE a cigarette from her exquisite silve case. THERESE notices that CAROL’S hands are lovely and smooth, salon manicured, in contrast to THERESE’S own. THERESE takes a cigarette from the case. CAROL lights THERESE’S cigarette and THERESE proceeds to smoke it, tho not without some effort.
So what kind of a name is Belivet?  25
It’s Czech. It’s changed. Originally-
It’s very original.
(she feels herself blush) Well.
And your first name?
Therese.
Therese. Not Ter-eeza.
No.
Therese Belivet. That’s lovely.
And yours?
Carol.
Carol. The WAITER reappears with their drinks and CAROL picks up glass and toasts.
Cheers.

(clinking glasses) Cheers. CAROL sips at her martini. THERESE watches her for a mome then samples hers. She tries to hide the surprise of its strength. CAROL smiles. THERESE (CONT’D) (beat) So, you - I’m sure you thought it was a man who sent back your gloves.  26
I did. I thought it might be a man in the ski department.
I’m sorry.
No, I’m delighted. I doubt very much if I’d have gone to lunch with him. THERESE watches as CAROL massages the back of her neck fo moment.
Your perfume -
Yes?
It’s nice.
Thank you. Harge bought me a bottle years ago, before we were married. I’ve been wearing it ever since.
Harge is your husband?
Yes. Well. Technically we - We’re divorcing.
(after a beat) I’m sorry.
(stubs out her cigarette) Don’t be. THERESE doesn’t know what to say. CAROL smiles, changes t subject.
And do you live alone, Therese Belivet?
I do. (beat) Well, there’s Richard. He wants to live with me. CAROL looks up at THERESE, raised eyebrow smile.  27 THERESE (CONT’D) No, it’s nothing like that. It’s - he'd like to marry me.
I see. Would you like to marry him? A pause.

(she makes light of it) I... barely know what to order for lunch. CAROL nods, almost looks past THERESE - what is she think about? Suddenly it seems to THERESE that CAROL’S mood has somehow darkened. The WAITER appears with their food. He sets their plates down. CAROL picks up her silverware, the cloud seemingly past.
I’m starved. Bon appetit. CAROL eats and THERESE watches, almost having to force herself to pick up her fork and knife and join her. But s does. CAROL looks up at her for a moment:
And what do you do on Sundays?
Nothing in particular. What do you do?

Nothing - lately. If you’d like to visit me some time, you’re welcome to. At least there’s some pretty country around where I live. Would you like to come out this Sunday? CAROL waits for THERESE’S answer.
Yes.
What a strange girl you are.
Why?

Flung out of space.  28 THERESE feels herself blush, and looks away from CAROL. S tries to attend to her lunch and martini. EXT. RESTAURANT. DAY. Through passing CROWDS, THERESE watches from just outside restaurant entrance as CAROL climbs into a convertible ac the street. CAROL’S best friend, ABBY, drives. She and CA greet each other with European-style kisses. Then CAROL t around and waves to THERESE. THERESE waves back as the ca takes off, disappearing into traffic. INT. ABBY’S CAR. DAY. ABBY snakes along Sixth Avenue.
I can just see Harge’s mother’s face when she sees me in this. Maybe I should stop home and change.
Don’t be a stupe.
Why don’t I just not show up?
Because I’1l be blamed. So you'd better just grin and bear it. (beat) You want to tell me about her? CAROL and ABBY exchange a brief glance.
Therese? (shrugs) She returned my gloves.
And?

And... if you don’t get us out of this traffic soon, I won’t have to worry about any damned party. (bundling up): Do you ever put the top up?  29 INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE LOCKER ROOM. DAY. THERESE sits opposite her open locker, now wearing her employee smock. She writes inside an appointment diary, o otherwise empty page, slowly and carefully in fountain pe Mrs. Carol Aird. Seventh Avenue entrance. 2:00 PM Sunday. She considers what she’s written, blows on the ink so it dries. EXT. NEW JERSEY. WEALTHY SUBURBS. EARLY EVENING. A well-kept road full of wealthy homes, green, sweeping l old wealth. ABBY’S car pulls into the circular drive of a large modern home, set back against a cloak of trees - th residence of HARGE’S boss, CY HARRISON. There’s clearly a party going on: music, laughter, well-dressed GUESTS arriving, valets opening doors, taking keys, etc. ABBY sh off the engine and turns to CAROL, who begins rummaging through her purse in sudden agitation.
Where on earth is my compact. God damn it. ABBY leans over towards CAROL, touches her arm.
You look fine. CAROL looks at ABBY.
Come in with me. Just for a minute.
Don’t even start. You’re the one who cancelled on us - you nitwit!
I know. I know. I’m sorry - I’m going! CAROL looks towards the house again, gathering herself.

Call me later. INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. DEN/LIVING ROOM - EARLY EVENING A large room for entertaining right off the foyer. Big, o fireplace. WAITERS circulate with food and drink. HARGE stands in a group with his parents, JOHN and JENNIFER, hi boss CY and CY’S wife, JEANETTE.  30
(to CY) I've tried to talk sense to the boy, Cy. I told him, son, Tri-State Capital’s not going to buy that Murray Hill parcel unless you improve your golf handicap.

(to his father, slight edge) I've got a few other things on my mind, Dad. A reserved silence, as they all know to what he’s referri HARGE looks off, sees CAROL in the foyer, handing her coa a VALET. HARGE (CONT’D) Excuse me. And he makes his way through the GUESTS to join CAROL. INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT The party in full-swing. A DANCE BAND plays “Harbour Ligh and HARGE and CAROL dance a slow fox-trot. CAROL notices other women, dressed much more formally than she. HARGE clocks this and draws her closer to him.
You're always the most beautiful woman in any room.

Tell your mother that. They look across the room to see JENNIFER watching them, indeed, looking as if she’d just swallowed a clove of gar INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. BUFFET/DINING ROOM - LATER Carol and Harge, and Cy and Jennifer are moving through t dinner buffet with their plates. JENNIFER hovers, tidying the display, and handing stray glasses and napkins to members of the staff.
We might hire a local boy to appear as Santa for Rindy, Christmas morning. If only we could find a way to get him down the chimney! (beat; to CAROL) How've you arranged it in the past, Carol?  31
What’s that?
Christmas morning. With Rindy. CAROL exchanges a brief look with HARGE before answering.
Oh, we... usually get up at dawn, Harge and I, and we - we wrap Rindy’s gifts together. Arrange them under the tree and wait for Rindy to wake. Which is - she normally-
(helps CAROL out) Usually, she’s down the stairs ina shot and barely notices us before she’s ripped through all the wrapping.
(smiles, grateful to
Yes. That’s right.
But no Santa Claus.
No.

Oh. Well. It is a production - May I serve you? JEANETTE offers CAROL a commiserating look: oh-brother. EXT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. LATER. CAROL and JEANETTE in the gardens. The party can be seen going on through a row of French doors. They smoke cigarettes. CAROL takes off her shoes, rubs her feet.
(takes a long deep drag on her cigarette) Keep an eye out, will you? Cy’1l scream if he catches me with this.
(laughs) What’1ll he do? Dock your allowance?  32
(very matter of fact) He doesn’t like me to smoke.
So? You like it. But they both know that it’s simply the way it is: wives defer to their husband’s wishes.
Carol, I - it’s really not my business, but if you’re going to be alone on Christmas, Cy and I would love to have you.
(she’s really touched by the offer) Thank you, Jeanette. CAROL takes another look inside the party: couples dancin through the tented plastic.

(watching the dancing) I don’t know. I might get away by myself. At least for a few days. INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPT. OFFICE. NIGHT. DANNIE ushers THERESE into the alluring world of a junior photo editor's office: the contact sheets dangling from l boards, the professional equipment, trays and lenses - bu mostly it’s the photos themselves that she’s in awe of. Candids, crime scenes, sports photos, everything that mak up the visual narrative of a newspaper. DANNIE sits at a and sets up dinner, a makeshift array brought from home - wrapped sandwiches, bottles of beer. THERESE breathes it in, not daring to touch anything.

Don’t worry, nothing’s gonna break if you pick it up. You want a sandwich? THERESE shakes her head, picks up a contact sheet and a magnifier and glances at the pictures. DANNIE watches her DANNIE (CONT’D) What are your pictures like?
They’re - probably not very good. I don’t know.  33
I mean, what are they? What are they of?
Trees. Birds. Windows. Anything, really. (beat) What do you write about?
People. A pause. THERESE looks through a camera lens at DANNIE. H looks up at her, she lowers the lens.
I feel strange, I think... taking pictures of people. It feels like - an intrusion or a-
Invasion of privacy?
Yes. DANNIE opens a beer, holds it out to THERESE. She takes i
Yeah but, all of us, we have, you know - affinities for people, right? THERESE doesn’t answer. DANNIE (CONT’D) Or certain people. There are certain people you like...
Sometimes.

And others you don’t. And you don’t really know why you’re attracted to some people and not others, the only thing you know is - you either are attracted or you’re not. It’s like physics - bouncing off each other like pin balls.
(smiles) So now you're a scientist?  34
Just trying to explain why I write about people rather than trees.
Sounds more like psychology.
Physics is more comforting. THERESE grabs a sandwich.
Yeah, but... Not everything’s as simple as a bunch of pin balls reacting, or...
Some things don’t even react. But everything's alive. A beat. DANNIE moves to THERESE, takes the beer bottle aw from her, puts it down. He puts his hand on THERESE’S shoulders.
It’s late. I should go. He kisses her, and she lets him, remaining very still. Th DANNIE steps back and THERESE looks down. THERESE (CONT’D) You shouldn't...
Why? Did you mind?
No.
Would Richard mind?
Probably. (beat) I have to go. THERESE gathers her things together, goes to the door.
Come back tomorrow? Or Wednesday?

Maybe. I don’t know. THERESE leaves.  35 EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LATE NIGHT. HARGE has brought CAROL home from the party. They stand together outside the door while CAROL fishes for her keys HARGE reaches into his pocket and produces his, opens doo
Here.
Thanks. And thanks for staying sober and driving me home. (kissing his cheek) Goodnight, Harge. She starts to go inside the house. HARGE stops her gently
Come to my parents for Christmas. We had a nice time tonight.
(not unkindly) It was one night.
I don’t like to think of you. Alone.
I’m not alone. There’s Rindy, there’s- She stops herself. HARGE knows what she was about to say.
Abby. There’s always Abby.
(after a pause) Abby and I were over long before you and I were over, Harge. (beat) I‘1l have Rindy packed and ready for you at four on Christmas Eve. She starts to step inside the house.
It shouldn't be like this.

I know. And she quietly shuts the door on HARGE.  36 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. The living room is dark and quiet. RINDY has fallen aslee the sofa; FLORENCE, on a chair opposite. CAROL gives FLOR a pat on her shoulder and squats down beside RINDY.
She wanted to wait up for you.
Ah, mama's special girl. CAROL brushes a strand of hair away from her eyes. She ge picks her up and carries her out of the room and up the stairs.

Goodnight, Florence. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. LATER CAROL lifts a holiday blanket from a small platform, revealing the assembled train set, set up behind a couch. switches on the train and watches it begin its slow route along the tracks. She sips at a nightcap. EXT. FRANKENBERG’S. SEVENTH AVENUE ENTRANCE. EARLY SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THERESE, in coat, scarf and gloves, waits for CAROL’S car pull up outside. RICHARD waits with her.
Where’s this place in Jersey?
The country, I think. I don’t really know.
My uncle Sal lives in Union City and he claims it’s pretty dangerous out there at night-
It’s not Union City.
Okay, okay. CAROL pulls up to the curb.
There’s my ride.  37 RICHARD accompanies THERESE to the car. He opens the door her, she gets in, shuts the door, rolls down the window. leans down to kiss her.
Eight o’clock?
Eight o’clock. RICHARD looks into the car, holds up a hand in greeting t CAROL.
Hi.
Hello. Carol Aird.
(leans across THERESE to shake CAROL’S hand) Richard Semco. Glad to meet you.
Likewise.
(to RICHARD) She wanted to meet you.
Therese speaks very highly of you.

(pleased to hear it) Well, that’s - swell. So you'll... get her back safe and sound? CAROL smiles, salutes her assent. THERESE is slightly embarrassed. RICHARD leans into the car and touches THERESE’S chin lightly. RICHARD (CONT’D) Love you. But THERESE has already rolled up the window, the car has started to go. RICHARD diminishes through the rear window INT. CAROL’S CAR. APPROACHING LINCOLN TUNNEL. DAY. CAROL and THERESE make their way cross town, as a cool wi sun combs through the car windows. CAROL appears at home behind the wheel - relaxed, confident.  38 To THERESE, the world inside CAROL’S car is a revelation, from the tan leather upholstery and mahogany dashboard to effortless style and elegance of its driver. The sounds o the world - even CAROL’S occasional chatter - have been replaced with the stillest MUSIC, the sound of air and li The presence of this older, sophisticated woman, who wear silk stockings and expensive perfume, is intoxicating and unnerving in equal measure. Even Carol’s purse, which res beside THERESE on the seat, is quite unlike anything she seen or examined so closely, full of mystery and make-up fragrances. From there her eyes wander down to CAROL’S le clad in smoky silk stockings. Glancing down at her own le wrapped in sensible wool tights, THERESE wonders if she w ever be the kind of woman who owns such a car and wears s clothes. The MUSIC broods slightly as THERESE looks straight ahead the car enters the Lincoln Tunnel. The car plunges into t semi-darkness as if entering a cocoon, a delirious descen which binds them together. She watches CAROL’S fingers gr the wheel, how CAROL squints slightly when she concentrat THERESE can barely suppress a tiny smile. But glancing ba CAROL suddenly appears to be miles away. CAROL switches o the car radio and Jo Stafford’s “You Belong to Me” comes THERESE leans back in her seat as they continue, speeding through the dark tunnel.

INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. (APRIL 1953) “You Belong To Me” also plays as several COUPLES DANCE, a them RICHARD and a PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN who he clutches tightly. THERESE, drinking a beer, watches them from a hallway just outside the living room. RICHARD catches sight of THERESE, tensing slightly, befor spinning his partner up and away from THERESE’S view. THE looks down, pulling out a cigarette from her purse and lighting it. She spots an attractive dark-haired woman on opposite side of the living room whose eyes are clearly o her. THERESE holds her gaze for a few seconds, but she ca feel herself blush, and she looks down. When she looks ba up, the WOMAN has disappeared. THERESE saunters a bit, glancing into the next room where she spots DANNIE and hi girlfriend LOUISE slow-dancing. They barely move, holding to each other the way people do when they’re newly in lov

39 INT./EXT. CAROL’S CAR. XMAS TREE LOT. NEW JERSEY. DAY. At a Christmas tree lot, THERESE sits in the car loading camera with film. When she’s done, she spots CAROL outsid a TEENAGED BOY ties up their tree, a large Doug Fir. The TEENAGED BOY has a bad cold and CAROL offers him tissues. THERESE steps out of the car, aims her camera and takes a shots. INT. CAROL’S CAR. RIDGEWOOD, NEW JERSEY. DAY. The car makes its way to Carol’s house, with the Douglas laid across the front and back seats between THERESE and CAROL. THERESE loves the feeling of the needles against her skin the way it smells, the way she knows that CAROL is beside her, though she can’t see her. The car comes to a halt in front of CAROL’S house. It’s a big house, a bigger house THERESE has ever been inside. CAROL turns off the engine.
You still with me?

Yes. CAROL opens her door, pops out of the car. THERESE is abo to get out of the car when she sees the front door of the house open and RINDY come tearing out to greet her mother FLORENCE stands in the doorway, ready to escort mother an daughter inside.
Mommyyyy!!

Hello, my darling! Guess what I brought you? I bet you’ll never guess... THERESE watches as mother and daughter proceed inside, chattering away. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. LATER. THERESE prepares a tray of tea and cookies. Through the o door we can see CAROL and RINDY in the living room, decorating the tree. Almost finished, CAROL is setting up ladder beside the tree.
Where’s the star?  40 RINDY roots around in the pile of ornaments, finds it.
This one, Mommy.
That's my girl. THERESE watches as CAROL ascends the ladder and places th star at the top of the tree.
Look how beautiful! CAROL descends the step ladder and joins Rindy, taking he into her lap.
Have you ever seen a more beautiful tree? And now... what comes after the star is placed?
More stars!
(tickling RINDY) I don't... think... so!
You find everything you need, miss? THERESE, startled, turns to see FLORENCE standing at the of the kitchen, near a back door.
Gosh, you scared me. How silly.

(she’s not sorry) I’m sorry, miss. (beat) I'1l take that through for Mrs. Aird. FLORENCE picks up the tray, walks through to the living r INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. A fire crackles in the fireplace as CAROL, seated under t tree, struggles to wrap the train set. THERESE sits at th piano, improvising, jumping from one bit of a tune to another. A half-empty bottle of white wine and a couple o glasses stand nearby.  4l
Were those pictures of me you were taking? At the tree lot? THERESE stops playing. A silence.
I’m sorry. I should have asked.
Don’t apologize.
I’ve been trying to... A friend of mine told me I should be more interested. In humans.
And how's that going?
(after a small beat) Well... actually.
I’m glad. THERESE begins to play “Easy Living.” CAROL listens for a moment, rises, walks over to Therese.
That’s beautiful. She grazes her hand on Therese’s shoulder. THERESE freeze and CAROL tries to lighten the moment with two quick stro to her cheek. THERESE continues to play and CAROL listens
Is that what you want to be? A photographer?
I think so. If I have any talent for it.

Isn't that something other people let you know you have? All you can do is - keep working. Use what feels right. Throw away the rest. THERESE finishes the song. CAROL starts over to a table b the couch, opens a cigarette box, takes one out, lights i
Will you show me your work? (she sits on the couch)  42
Sure. I mean, I haven’t sold anything. Or even shown a picture to anyone who could buy one. I don’t even have a decent camera. But... they’re all at my place. Under the sink, mostly.

Invite me round. From outside, the sound of a car pulling into the drivewa Car door opens and slams. The moment broken, CAROL rises quickly, and marches toward the front door. CAROL comes out of the living room and finds HARGE in the entry, restringing the mistletoe.
Harge. What’s wrong?

Nothing. Does there have to be a problem for me to visit my wife? HARGE approaches CAROL, reaching out to greet her, but st spotting THERESE at the piano in the living room. He look CAROL and CAROL looks away. Then HARGE moves past CAROL d the hall and into the kitchen. THERESE clocks it all. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. LATER. THERESE browses through a book, alone in the living room, she hears CAROL and HARGE conversing in the kitchen. Thro the cracked door she catches glimpses of CAROL pacing to fro, anxiously smoking, and hears the sounds of HARGE repairing a pipe under the kitchen sink. She tries occupy herself, perusing titles of books from the bookshelf.
... that’s not fair, Harge. We agreed that Rindy would stay with me until Christmas Eve.
What do you suggest I do? - You think I prefer traipsing off to West Palm Beach for the holiday? It was all mother’s doing-
But I’m not - ready - She’s not packed - she’s asleep in bed! What about my Christmas with my daughter-
I’m sorry, Carol, but it can’t be helped. The flight’s in the morning - You think I've packed?... (the sound of dropped tools)-Goddamnit!

INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. CONTINUOUS. HARGE emerges from beneath the sink, having hurt his hand CAROL goes to help him up. But as he does he spots THERES through the door. He marches over and opens it fully. THE looks caught, startled. A silence.
How do you know my wife?
Harge, please...
I - work at Frankenberg’s. The department store.
I ordered a gift from her desk. I forgot my gloves. She returned them. I thanked her.

(to CAROL) That’s bold. HARGE sizes THERESE up for a moment before he turns back the kitchen. He walks past CAROL and exits into a cloakro at the back of the house where we hear sounds of his clea up. CAROL, exasperated, approaches the living room doorwa
Can I - do-

Just... leave it be. CAROL gently shuts the door. THERESE is left standing the shut out. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. NIGHT. A UNIFORMED CHAUFFEUR sits at the wheel of Harge’s car, a and silent, as CAROL bundles RINDY into the back seat. FLORENCE puts her bags in the trunk as HARGE waits with a cigarette and drink outside the front door.  44

Remember: in bed by seven. I know how you take advantage of Grandma Jennifer. (beat) Okay, snow flake. Gimme a big one. (she hugs RINDY tightly and kisses her) You're going to have the most wonderful Christmas, I promise. RINDY pulls back from the hug. She has an idea.
There’s room for you in the car, Mommy. You can come with us!

Oh, darling, I - wish I could... but sometimes... Mommies and Daddies decide there isn’t enough room for them both in the same place at the same time- (unable to go further) And Mommy has to be here to make sure Santa’s elf doesn’t give your presents to another little girl. You wouldn’t want that, would you? RINDY gives her a bright smile and CAROL hugs her, and ki her eyelids. CAROL clocks the CHAUFFEUR watching her thro the rear view mirror, and quickly looks away. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS MUSIC PLAYS softly from the phonograph ("El Americano” by Xavier Cugal and his Orchestra) as THERESE tidies up, try to make herself useful. She can see CAROL through the bay window, shutting the car door and starting back toward th house, wearing only a thin sweater around her shoulders. She sees HARGE step off of the front porch, stub out his cigarette, and walk towards CAROL. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. CAROL heads to the front door, but HARGE pulls her back towards him. A silence, as he takes her hand in one of hi He can hear the MUSIC from inside the house. He sways a little.
You smell good.
You're drunk.  45 He pulls her closer to him, he closes his eyes, tries to dance with her.
Harge, I’m cold. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS. Through the open front door THERESE can see HARGE stumble back slightly, away from CAROL and CAROL grabbing his arm right him.
Let me get you some coffee.
(a bit drunk) I’m not drunk. HARGE takes a step towards CAROL. THERESE ducks back into living room, not wishing to overhear any more.
You can still come with us. Go pack a bag.
I can’t do that.
Sure, you can. It’s easy. We can buy you a ticket in the morning. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. HARGE tries to take her hand, she backs away.
What? You’re going to spend Christmas with Abby? Is that it? Or with your - shop girl?
Stop it, Harge.
I put nothing past women like you.

You married a woman like me.  46 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS. THERESE goes to the phonograph, increases the volume slightly, so that she can hear only the rising and fallin the voices outside. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. HARGE reaches out to grab CAROL, she backs away. He stumb falls onto his knees. A silence, as he catches his breath
Come with me now. If you don’t - if you - let me - open that car door - if you won’t come-
(she interrupts him) Then what? Then it’s over? HARGE is about to respond, but he suddenly realizes he’s his hands and knees, drunk, before CAROL, who is very sti and very silent.
