No - You shouldn’t have. But CAROL is pleased, and THERESE is pleased that she’s pleased.
Open it. She watches CAROL unwrap the package. It’s the Billie Hol record with “Easy Living” on it. THERESE (CONT’D) I played it for you. At your house.
I remember. (beat; she looks up at THERESE) Thank you. THERESE picks up her camera, focuses on CAROL, and snaps picture. CAROL brings her hands up to her face.
Oh God, I look a fright - don’t -

You do not, you look... (she leans over and takes them back down)wonderful... Just - stay like that. THERESE realizes she’s holding CAROL'S hands in her own. quickly looks around the diner, feeling slightly embarras but no one else is looking. CAROL clocks this, squeezing THERESE’S hands and gently extricating herself.  72
Do you miss Richard?
(she thinks about it) No. I haven’t thought about him all day. Or of home.

Home. THERESE regrets using the word, watching CAROL’s mood dar slightly. INT/EXT. PHILLY DINER. INNER PHILADELPHIA. LATER. THERESE returns from the ladies room at the rear of the diner, walking past a WOMAN IN HER THIRTIES gathering her THREE YOUNG CHILDREN. At first THERESE doesn’t see CAROL, then spots her through the window, at a pay telephone. Sh sees her inserting her change and quickly dialing a numbe HEAR THE RINGS: Once. Twice. Three times. CAROL glances toward the diner window. Through the glass one of the WOM CHILDREN is making faces through the precipitation. Just beyond is THERESE, paying the bill at the counter. CAROL replaces the receiver in its cradle before the call can b answered. THERESE turns to exit the diner and spots CAROL smoking a cigarette. INT/EXT. CAROL’S CAR. NIGHT. CAROL drives. THERESE is sleeping, huddled up against the passenger side window. A blanket partly covers her. RADIO V.O. .»+-and that concludes our Holiday Greetings from President-elect and Mrs. Eisenhower. This is WOR- Pittsburgh wishing you and yours- CAROL takes one hand off the steering wheel and pulls up blanket so THERESE is covered.

head_text.subj: EXT. TWO-LANE HIGHWAY OUTSIDE OF PITTSBURGH. NIGHT

text: CAROL'S car glides along the empty road, behind it, the e glow of the Pittsburgh industrial skyline, ahead of it: p darkness.  73 EXT. ABBY’S HOUSE. NIGHT. We see HARGE rushing out of the rear door of his car, his CHAUFFEUR idling, and rushing up the walk of a dark, brickfront bungalow. INT. ABBY’S HOUSE. Ferocious banging on the front door as ABBY rushes down stairs, tying up a robe as she goes. She opens the door. HARGE, in a state, breathing hard.
I have to speak to her.
What are you doing? - You're supposed to be in Florida.
(after a beat) I couldn't do it. I had to - Rindy - she wanted to see her mother on Christmas. Not that it’s any of your business. Just go get her. I know she’s here.
You’ve got some fucking nerve ordering me around. And, no. She’s not here.
That’s impossible. She’s not home. She’s not with me. She must be with you.

(after a moment) Yeah, you know, Harge, you have a point. You’ve spent ten years making damned sure her only point of reference is you, her only focus in life is you, your job, your friends, your family, your-
WHERE IS SHE. (beat; he composes himself) She's still my wife, Abby. I’m responsible for her.
Well, you know, that’s some way of showing it, Harge - slapping her with an injunction. I’m closing the door.  74 ABBY starts to close it but HARGE intercepts.
I love her.
I can’t help you with that. ABBY quietly shuts the door. But each remains unmoving a moment, in the dark.
THERESE is stepping out of her room with her suitcase, dressed for the day. She walks over to the next room and quietly knocks on the door.
Carol? When there’s no answer, she tries the door. It’s open.

head_text.subj: INT. MOTEL ROOM. OUTSIDE PITTSBURGH. DAY

text: THERESE peeks her head into the room, to the sound of run water from the bathroom. She sees CAROL’s overnight case open on her bed, her things spread about the room.
Therese, is that you?
Yes!
Would you be a sweetie and fetch my red knit sweater? It’s in the small suitcase. Upper left hand side.

Okay. THERESE finds the case, opens it. She takes a moment to l at CAROL’S clothes in the case before she actually touche them, feeling the fabrics, the silks and cashmeres, takin their powdery smells. Something at the bottom of the case catches her eye. A glint of metal beneath some stockings. removes the stockings, revealing a small, pearl-handled pistol. She reaches out, tentatively, to touch it, just a CAROL calls out from the bathroom.
Hey, slowpoke...  75 THERESE quickly withdraws her hand and hurriedly replaces CAROL'S clothing. She grabs the red sweater.

Found it. THERESE takes the sweater to the bathroom door and knocks lightly. The door opens, revealing CAROL standing there w a towel wrapped around her. Steam filters out of the bathroom. THERESE hesitates a moment, then hands her the sweater.
Everything all right?
Yeah - I’m just - suddenly starving.

(closing the door): I won't be a minute. INT. CAROL’S CAR. ON THE ROAD. DAY. CAROL drives, looking out on the increasingly frozen landscape. THERESE is grabbing a sandwich from a basket o the back seat. CAROL’S packed suitcase rests beside it. THERESE settles back into her seat.
Do you feel safe? With me, I mean?
(laughs) You're full of surprises. THERESE continues thinking, eating her sandwich.
But - Do you? CAROL glances at her. THERESE holds her gaze. CAROL turns attention back to the road.
It’s the wrong question.
But you’d tell me. If something scared you. And I could help. CAROL shakes her head, smiles.

I’m not frightened, Therese.  76 THERESE considers this, then glances back at CAROL, who p out at the open road, the cool winter sun skating across face. EXT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. DUSK. CAROL'S car pulls into the drive of a small motel with an elaborate and large painted likeness of William McKinley wood billboard. INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. DUSK. The front desk of the blonde-wood hotel office. A very pr HOTEL MANAGER assists CAROL, checking in.
Our standard rooms come equipped with stereophonic console radios, or if you prefer, the Presidential Suite is available. At a very attractive rate.
(thinks a moment, then) Two standard rooms should be fine.

Why not take the Presidential Suite? CAROL and THERESE exchange a look. THERESE (CONT’D) If the rate’s attractive... EXT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. NIGHT. THERESE at the ice dispenser. She’s bundled up in scarf, gloves, overcoat - but wearing bunny slippers. She strugg to fill an ice bucket, shivering.
Can I - hold that for you? THERESE looks up. A tall, affable looking young man with spectacles appears beside her, holding up the lid of the dispenser while she fills her bucket.
Thank you. It’s cold.
So cold my glasses'’ve fogged clear over.  77
Thanks again. G’night.

Night. He tips his hat to her and THERESE heads back to her room INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL ROOM. NIGHT. True to its name, framed photographs of William McKinley his wife hang over the twin beds. Also adorning the suite dressing table with a fan-shaped mirror, bedside cabinets gold-specked table lamps, striped wall paper. A record pl on THERESE’s portable turntable, (”Easy Living (1933 vers by Billie Holiday). THERESE sits beside CAROL at the dres table as CAROL carefully applies mascara to THERESE’S las
Don’t blink. (beat) Now look at you. CAROL turns THERESE around to the mirror.

I need lipstick. CAROL chooses a lipstick, gives it to THERESE and watches THERESE applies it. CAROL hands THERESE a tissue. THERESE blots, hands CAROL the tissue. THERESE (CONT’D) Next? CAROL picks up a perfume bottle, hands it to THERESE.

Would mademoiselle be so kind as to apply at the pulse points only? THERESE applies perfume to the inside of her wrists, the crook of her arms, and her neck. She turns to CAROL. CARO holds out her wrists to THERESE.
Me, too. THERESE applies perfume to the same spots on CAROL. CAROL closes her eyes, arches her neck back slightly.

That’s divine. Smell that. A beat, and THERESE leans forward to smell CAROL’S perfum  78 INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL ROOM. LATE NIGHT. From her neighboring twin bed, THERESE watches CAROL slee Very gently, she slips out of her bed and sits down silen on the edge of CAROL'S bed, and watches her breath. She quietly lifts a finger and lightly runs it along CAROL’S cheek. CAROL turns over in her sleep. THERESE waits to be sure CAROL won’t wake, then returns to her own bed. INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL OFFICE. MORNING. THERESE is seated in the improvised breakfast room, made of a few mismatched tables and chairs, and a paltry sprea coffee, juice and rolls. She spots the YOUNG MAN from the dispenser pouring himself a cup of coffee, carrying a lar black case. He spots THERESE and smiles broadly.
Good morning. Glad to see you didn’t freeze over or nothing.
You too. Before she can even respond he’s setting down his cup and pulling up a chair. THERESE spots CAROL arriving with a r map, making a beeline to the coffee.
Not the best coffee I’m afraid.
Long as it’s hot.
What’s in the case?
Oh. Notions. I’m a - I sell them. Or try to. CAROL arrives opposite Therese and plops down.
Lousy coffee.
(surprised by her arrival) Sorry- (he attempts to stand)
Excuse me?
We were just chatting.  79
Name’s Tucker... Tommy.
(extending her hand) Therese Belivet. Carol Aird.
(shaking hands) Pleased to meet you.
Mr. Tucker sells notions. THERESE makes a gesture to his case, which CAROL regards.
I see.
(brief silence) Don’t really know what notions are, exactly. But they do instruct us to use the word. Says it appeals to women. So... (beat) I did sell a shoe-horn yesterday to a feller in Wheeling.
(trying to help him out) Do you sell lipstick?
No. But I have a sewing kit. (beat) You don’t need a sewing kit. I can tell. CAROL smiles politely, but returns her attention to the m
(to THERESE) We should make Chicago by five or six, if we get an early start.
That’s where I’m headed. There’s a short cut across the interstates, knocks two hours off the drive.
Two hours, that’s... That would be great-—
Can we stop to buy some magazines?  80
(reaching for his case) I got Field and Stream... National Geographic?
Popular Photography?
(a beat as he smiles) Nope. Course not. I am doomed to remain without a sale. THERESE throws a little smile to CAROL, as TOMMY shakes h head. MUSIC picks up, carrying over the following scenes.

The wide open road stretches out before us as CAROL'S car comes gliding by. INT. CAROL’S CAR. LATER. DAY Inside, THERESE enjoys the sweet boredom of nothing but t in CAROL'S company. She scans the radio dial.
CAROL and THERESE, bundled in coats and scarves, sit on t low branch of a tree, just off the road, sharing sandwich and thermos coffee. ]

The shimmering entrance to Chicago’s Drake Hotel is a swa of taxis, GUESTS and BELL-HOPS. CAROL and THERESE, bleary from the road, come to a stop and begin quickly gathering their things from the car. INT. DRAKE HOTEL ROOM. LATER. A BELLBOY carries CAROL and THERESE’S bags into an opulen room. We hear CAROL tip and thank him as we follow THERES into her first encounter with hotel luxury. CAROL collaps onto one of the beds.
Finally. A real bed. Heaven. THERESE inspects the room like a detective. She bends to her hand through the carpet.  81

This carpet - it feels like woven silk! Like we shouldn’t be stepping on it. And the furniture! She turns to look at CAROL... fast asleep on the bed. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. RESTAURANT. LATER. Carol speaks to the hostess as Therese observes the busy hotel restaurant, with WAITERS moving briskly and efficie through the room.
Table for two, please, for dinner.
Are you staying here at the hotel?
Yes, it’s room... (she searches for her key)
623. Mrs. Aird.
That’ll be just a moment, Mrs. Aird.
Thank you. Therese eyes the gifts and souvenirs at the counter: fanc boxes of candy, souvenir key rings, pens. She lifts a can specialty Virginia ham.
Do you think something like this would appeal to an older woman?
I suppose. Depends on the woman.
I worked with a woman at Frankenberg’s - Ruby. But she depressed me.
Why?
She’s old. Alone. No money. It’s - silly, I know.  82
I think it’s a lovely gesture. Send it. Here. CAROL picks up the order form and pencil and hands it to THERESE.
Mrs. Aird, your table is ready.

Thank you. Therese takes the form and pencil with her as they are le their table. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. PHONE BOOTH. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL in a phone booth placing a call. She can see THERES from the booth, who stands in line to collect general delivery mail. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. CHICAGO. DAY. CONTINUOUS. THERESE on line to pick up her mail. She looks around for CAROL, spots her dialing in the phone booth... INT. HARGE’S OFFICE. NEW YORK. DAY. His private phone rings. He picks up.
Hargess Aird. Hello. Nothing from the other end.

All right, Carol. Enough is enough. Now where are you, goddamnit?... Hello? INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE PHONE BOOTH. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL, suddenly unable to respond, leans her head against phone box a moment, then quietly hangs up the phone. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL joins THERESE at the post desk. THERESE has picked few letters.  83
(refers to the letters) Someone’s popular.
All from Richard. (she puts the letters in her bag) Aren't you going to check your mail?
Nobody knows I’m here.
Were you... making a call?

What? No - Ladies room. Carol throws her scarf over her head and starts out. Ther watches her a moment as she goes, then follows. EXT. LAKE SHORE DRIVE. CHICAGO. NEW YEAR’S EVE. DAY. CAROL and THERESE stand at the side of the frozen road, considering a flat tire. CAROL starts rummaging through h purse when she looks up and hears a car coming.

Here’s one. THERESE tries to flag down the approaching motorist for h A dark-colored ‘42 Chrysler Sedan slows to a stop and pul over ahead of them. The driver backs up, revealing it to TOMMY TUCKER, the notions salesman.
Well - what in the world. (to Carol): Look who just...
What do you know? I thought that might be the two of you. TOMMY hops out of his car and approaches the women. He inspects the tire.
Yep, that’s a flat alright. Just hope you didn’t dent that rim.
I felt something pulling, and then a grinding-  84
Right. Well. Can I jack her up for you?
We - don’t think there is one.
No jack?
(glancing at CAROL) We think it might have been left at home.
Long story.
Bigger problem is, we think it might be flat. The spare.
Gotcha. Well... I got a jack. I can jack her up for you. We just use my spare.
But what about you?
Me I’m heading home from here - I got plenty of spares back home. (inspecting the flat) Don’t think there’s rim damage. Shouldn’t take too long I don’t expect.
There’s just... one other thing...

What’s that, ma’am? INT/EXT. TOMMY’S CAR. LAKE SHORE DRIVE. LATER. DAY. In the front seat, THERESE offers CAROL some coffee from thermos. Radio softly plays. Up ahead, TOMMY leans over t hood, his hands black from a lengthy operation.
I’m ravenous.  Silence. 85
So am I.
(watching him work) We're lucky we found him.
I’ll say. THERESE (CONT’D) Are you sorry we came?
On the trip? No. Are you?
No. They look up to the sound of CAROL’s car starting up agai TOMMY climbs out of the drivers seat and approaches, dust himself off. CAROL and THERESE get out to meet him.
Wonderful!
Well... It’ll get you to your next stop, but you best get it checked at a garage. New hose. They’1l tell ya the same.
Thank you so much.
Tommy, what do we owe you.
Oh, please - nothing at all, ma’am.
Well for the tire at least.
No need. Like I said, I’ve got a collection. Occupational hazard.
Well. Thank you. Again. For everything.  86
You are surely welcome, ma’am. CAROL starts off to the car, leaving an uncertain beat between TOMMY and THERESE. TOMMY TUCKER (CONT’D) And Happy New Year.
Yes, that’s right. Happy New Year to you.

Yep, well, I’m counting on a big night for sales. Stocking up on hats and sparklers. I’m hopeful. THERESE smiles as he back-steps, tips his hat and gets in his car. She glances at CAROL, climbing into the car - an feels a sudden surge of longing. EXT. WATERLOO, IOWA. EARLY EVENING. On the road leading into Waterloo, CAROL’S car speeds by billboard sign with a cartoon of Napoleon being strangled Nelson. In fancy script below the cartoon is written: WATERLOO BECKONS. POP. 12,070. The sky is a deep red. INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. NIGHT. Twin beds, quilted headboards, the usual. Radio tuned int Guy Lombardo’s New Year’s Eve broadcast from the Waldorf Astoria. It’s almost midnight. A couple of chipped plasti trays carrying the remnants of some ham and cheese sandwi are set on one of the beds. CAROL sits sipping beer from Champagne flute, her hair wrapped in a towel. Each dresse robes, CAROL watches THERESE brush out her hair at a dres table. The countdown to the New Year begins on the radio. Five. Four. Three. Two. One: HAPPY NEW YEAR! And the fami Lombardo signature “Auld Lang Syne” begins, but neither w takes notice. Instead CAROL gets up from the bed, takes t brush from THERESE and begins to brush THERESE’S hair, slowly, carefully. When she’s done, she puts the brush do and turns THERESE around to face her.
Happy New Year.

Happy New Year. They face each other in silence, listening to the faraway radio broadcast - a moment when anything could happen.  87 THERESE, for the first time, reaches out ever so slightly brush her fingers against CAROL’S. CAROL looks down at th fingertips touching.
Harge and I never spend New Year’s Eve together. There’s always a business function, always clients to entertain.

I’ve always spent it alone. In crowds. (beat) I’m not alone this year. THERESE squeezes CAROL'S hand ever so slightly. The Guy Lombardo band strikes up a bright New Year’s tune. CAROL unties her robe and lets it fall open, revealing he nakedness to THERESE. It’s so still, it’s as if all breat the room were suspended. THERESE stands up to join her, a CAROL takes her face gently in both her hands. She kisses THERESE’S lips. It’s a wondrous kiss for them both, slow unhurried. Afterwards, CAROL removes her hands from THERE face and eases off the towel from her head.
I’m sorry.
For what?
For everything that might happen. Later.
(after a moment) Take me to bed. CAROL moves towards THERESE, takes her in her arms, leads to the bed.
Lie down. THERESE does. CAROL lets her own robe drop to the floor t opens THERESE’s robe on the bed, taking in her youthful beauty.
I never looked like that. She climbs onto the bed and straddles THERESE. She stroke her face, her hair. THERESE closes her eyes, but begins t tremble involuntarily.  88
You're trembling. CAROL leans down to kiss her lightly on the forehead, the reaches across the bed to shut off the light. THERESE sto her.

Don’t. I want to see you. CAROL nods, then slides down THERESE’S body and stops jus below THERESE’S navel. She kisses her belly, moves down THERESE’S body with her mouth. THERESE looks up at the ceiling, trying to quell her body’s shuddering of nerves. closes her eyes. CAROL slides up THERESE’S body and plays with one of THERESE’S nipples with the tip of her tongue. THERESE moans softly. She pulls CAROL up to her mouth and they kiss eagerly, passionately. THERESE opens her eyes a regards CAROL’S face, so close to hers, and smiles.
(a whisper) My angel. Flung out of space. They begin to make love for the very first time.

head_text.subj: INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. DAY

text: Morning light filters through the drawn curtains as THERE still in bed, watches CAROL packing up for the day ahead. suddenly, this day, everything in the world is different.
What town are we in?

This? Waterloo. Isn’t that awful? INT. OFFICE. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. LATER. The deserted office is strewn with empty beer bottles and cheap New Year’s decoration. CAROL looks around for a cle rings the desk bell. An ANCIENT WOMAN shuffles on out of back room. She wears a party hat.
You the folks in thirteen?
We're checking out.
Telegram come for you last night.  89 The ANCIENT WOMAN shuffles on out of the room and comes b with a telegram. She gives it to CAROL. CAROL opens the telegram. Reads it. It’s not good news.
When did this arrive?

I ain’t a clock, lady. Early. Seven. Nine. EXT. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. MORNING. CAROL storms out of the office, tearing past the patchy remains of snow, where THERESE is loading the car with th belongings. CAROL pulls open the driver's side door, searching for something she doesn’t see, and slams the do shut. She runs up to the cabin they just vacated and tear open the door, almost immediately comes out again, slammi shut the door. She’s furious.
Carol! What the hell-
(focusing on THERESE) Where's my suitcase?
Carol - wait a minute - what’s going on?

(she snaps) I want my fucking suitcase. CAROL storms over to the trunk, brushing past THERESE on way. She finds her suitcase, flings it open and starts rifling through it. She finds the pistol. THERESE tries t block her way.
What are you doing with that? Carol - what happened?! CAROL pushes past THERESE. EXT./INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. MORNING. CAROL kicks at the door of the cabin next to their’s.
Open up in there! You hear me? Right now!  90 THERESE runs up to the door to join CAROL.
Carol, you're scaring me, you can’t-

Stand out of the way, Therese. Carol reaches for the door and finds it unlocked. She kic the door open and takes aim. TOMMY TUCKER stands inside getting dressed, trousers half on, half off. He wears his hat. He grabs his spectacles off a table and slips them o the end of his nose. On the unmade bed before him is his black case, opened to reveal an elaborate reel-to-reel ta recorder and sophisticated microphones. THERESE stares at equipment, uncomprehending. CAROL cocks her pistol and assumes the shooting stance, aiming directly at TOMMY’S h

(CONT'D) (to TOMMY) Where’s the tape, you sonofabitch. She enters the room, starts pulling apart the case, the equipment, all the while keeping the pistol aimed at TOMM TOMMY continues to dress himself, rather calmly.
How much is Harge paying you for this? I’1l give you double, triple. Anything you want.
I wish I could oblige you, ma‘am. But the tape is already on its way to your husband.
That can’t be right.

(shrugs) My reputation rests on my efficiency, Mrs. Aird. A tense pause. CAROL moves towards TOMMY. He remains quit calm, still. But he keeps his eye on her all the while. C advances closer, aiming the pistol at his head.
How do I know you’re not lying?

(a beat) You don’t, ma’am.  91 CAROL tenses up, putting her index finger on the trigger. at once she whirls around to the recording equipment, poi the gun to it, and pulls the trigger - but the gun just clicks. She tries again, but the trigger jams. In utter frustration she hurls the gun at the recording equipment. THERESE, who’s been hovering by the door, moves towards CAROL.

Carol... CAROL, exhausted and distraught, gives THERESE the telegr and moves outside of the cabin. She slumps against the railing. THERESE exchanges a look with TOMMY, who’s still cool as cucumber. THERESE retrieves the gun, joins CAROL outside. CAROL lights a cigarette, looks out towards the highway. THERESE reads the telegram, then looks up through the doo TOMMY, still standing half dressed in his cabin. THERESE (CONT’D) (to TOMMY) How could you.
I am a professional, Miss Belivet. It’s nothing personal. A silence. CAROL smokes, THERESE shakes her head at TOMMY disgusted, not wanting to believe this is happening. TOMM tips his hat to THERESE.

Let’s get out of here. EXT. ALLEY. WATERLOO. LATER. THERESE, carrying pistol and telegram, finds some trash b in an alley. She lifts the lid on one and tosses the pist into it, but it lodges on top. She buries it with one han and does her best to clean it off with the telegram. She tosses back the lid and hurries back to the street, round the corner. There she finds CAROL at a pay phone. She ste back instinctively, but overhears the end of CAROL’S call ABBY.

+. earliest flight into LaGuardia is tomorrow afternoon... Oh Abby, I don’t know how to fix this - I haven't the strength... THERESE wishes she could hold CAROL in her arms at this moment. But she knows she can’t.  92 INT. CAROL’S CAR. EARLY EVENING. CAROL drives in silence as they approach Chicago. THERESE smokes a cigarette. You could cut the tension with a knif
You shouldn’t smoke. You'll get a cough. (silence) What are you thinking?... You know how many times a day I ask you that?
I’m sorry. What am I thinking? I’m thinking that I am utterly selfish. And I-
Don’t do this. You had no idea. How could you have known?

I - I should have said no to you. But I never say no. And it’s selfish because I take - everything. Because I don’t know - anything. I don’t - know what I want. How could I if I just say yes to everything? THERESE begins to cry, softly. CAROL pulls over to the si of the road, against a frozen bank of snow. She turns THE towards her. She dries her tears. CAROL and THERESE regar each other, calmly, steadily.
I took what you gave willingly. A pause. CAROL runs a finger along THERESE’S cheek. She t back to the wheel. Restarts the car.

It’s not your fault, Therese - Alright? More silence. CAROL, at a loss to make the situation bett accelerates quickly onto the highway. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. CHICAGO. NIGHT. CAROL is finishing a call with ABBY, sitting on one of th twin beds, smoking. THERESE emerges from the bathroom, switching off the light. She stands for a moment in the d before she climbs into the other bed.  93

Thank you, pet... Oh, you know. Shattered. Sickened... I hope so... No... Talk tomorrow... And thank you... I will. Night. She hangs up the phone and looks down a moment. Then she turns to THERESE with a sad tenderness.

You don’t have to sleep over there. Silence. THERESE gets up, joins CAROL in the other bed. C wraps her arms and legs around THERESE, kissing her gentl the eyes, the lips. THERESE looks at her deeply and then kisses her back, a long, lingering, searching kiss. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. CHICAGO. MORNING. A ribbon of daylight over THERESE’s face. Eyes still shut she reaches out for CAROL, but CAROL’S not there. No soun coming from the bathroom. She lifts her head and checks t clock: 8 AM. THERESE sits up in the bed. There, seated in armchair in the semi-darkness, is ABBY. She smokes a cigarette. And all at once THERESE understands what CAROL absence means. Silence.
She’s gone?
Early this morning.
Is she coming back?
No. Piercing silence.
This is all my fault.
Nonsense. ABBY puts out her cigarette, gets up and pulls open the curtains. Cold, bright sunlight streams into the room.
We should get going.  94 INT. ROADSIDE DINER OUTSIDE OF CHICAGO. DAY. THERESE stares out the window; she hasn’t touched her mea
Eat something. (no response) Suit yourself. ABBY slides THERESE’S plate to her side of the table and starts finishing it. THERESE turns to her.
Why don’t you like me? I’ve never done anything to you. A pause. ABBY starts to say something, thinks better of i She leans in towards THERESE.
You really think I’ve flown halfway across the country to drive you back East because I hate you and want to see you suffer?
It’s for Carol. Not for me.
(after a beat) That’s - If you really believe that then you’re not as smart as I thought you were. Therese takes this in, then looks up at Abby. Silence.
With you and Carol... what happened?

It’s completely different - I’ve known Carol since I was 10 years old... (after a long beat) It was... back when we had the furniture store. Late one night. My Ford broke down near my Mother’s house and... We tried to stay up, but... curled up together in my old twin bed. And that was it... Fora while. And then it changed. It changes. Nobody’s fault. (beat) So... She opens her purse and searches inside. She produces an envelope.  95
Here - she...
What? ABBY hands her a letter. EXT. ROADSIDE DINER. MOMENTS LATER. In a WIDE lonely frame we see THERESE has stepped outside diner to tear open the letter. As she reads, we hear CARO voice:

Dearest. There are no accidents and he would have found us one way or another. Everything comes full circle. Be grateful it was sooner rather than later. You’1l think it harsh of me to say so, but no explanation I offer will satisfy you. We see ABBY leave the diner as THERESE continues reading. climbs in the car and starts the engine. A soft undertone MUSIC has emerged. INT. ANOTHER MOTEL. NIGHT. ABBY in the bathroom, washing out some clothes. Through a crack in the door, she spots THERESE, seated on the bed, drained by tears, expressionless.

Please don’t be angry when I tell you that you seek resolutions and explanations because you’re young. But you will understand this one day. INT./EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. ABBY pulls the car off the road near a small grove of tre and fading clumps of snow. THERESE jumps out, makes for t trees and tries to hide herself before she throws up. ABB lights a cigarette and remains in the car, watching THERE from a distance.

And when it happens, I want you to imagine me there to greet you like the morning sky, our lives stretched out ahead of us, a perpetual sunrise.  96 INT. CAROL’S CAR. NIGHT. ABBY, at the wheel, glances in the rear-view-mirror at THERESE, stretched out asleep on the back seat of the car Distant passing lights comb over her repose.

But until then, there must be no contact between us. I have much to do, and you, my darling, even more. Please believe that I would do anything to see you happy and so I do the only thing I can - I release you. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. NEW YORK. DAY. THERESE, in her overcoat, suitcase beside her, stands in middle of her apartment. It’s full of her things, but it looks like a foreign land. All the photographs on the wal seem as if they were taken by someone else. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. THAT SAME NIGHT. THERESE hunches over her sink, bathed in red light. She t a quick deep drag of a cigarette, burning in an ashtray. of negatives hang from hooks underneath the kitchen cupboards, over the trays of chemicals. She finds a certa shot on the enlarger, marks it, and focuses. She begins t process of developing the print. Finally, she watches the photo in its bath slowly appear shadow here and there, a shape forming - and it’s CAROL, asleep on her back, her body akimbo in a tumble of sheets one hand resting delicately. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY. LATE NIGHT. THERESE is creeping down the half-lit stairway. She picks the phone without making a sound and stares at the dial. hangs up. Then in one continuous gesture she picks it up again and dials the number. She stands frozen. One long r Silence. Another long ring. Then someone picks up the lin But there’s silence on the other end. Nothing. THERESE is frozen.

Hello? (beat) Carol? The silence that follows is like an answer. THERESE holds receiver close: a precious thing.  97 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. CAROL in the dark, on the other end, still. She makes a movement as if to say something, but doesn’t. We see her finger softly graze the receiver button before pressing i down. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY PHONE. NIGHT. Extremely CLOSE on THERESE hearing CAROL disconnect, but holding on in the void.

(prayerful) I miss you. I miss you. INT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. NEW JERSEY. DAY. HARGE, CAROL, JENNIFER and JOHN are seated together for a weekday lunch, with everything distinctly in its place. Eisenhower's inauguration proceedings can be heard and glimpsed on the living room television set.
More mashed potatoes, Carol?
Yes - Thanks. They’re delicious. CAROL reaches over to take the bowl of mashed potatoes, b HARGE gets to it first, spoons some out for CAROL. The atmosphere is polite, but far from relaxed.
Thank you. (beat) I thought... perhaps... Chester and Marge would be here by now. With Rindy...
Marge said to go ahead, not to wait.
(to CAROL) I’m sure they’1l be here soon. CAROL appreciates HARGE’S small kindness.
Harge tells us you’ve been getting along quite well with your doctor, Carol.  98
And why shouldn’t she be getting on well. He’s a very expensive doctor.
He’s actually not a doctor but a psychotherapist.
Well he comes very well regarded.
(to HARGE) A Yale man, like your uncle.
(ever so slightly edgy) But that doesn’t make him a doctor. HARGE throws her a little look.

I do like him. Very much. He’s been a great help. JENNIFER and JOHN continue eating in silence. INT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. LATER. CAROL sits alone near the living room window, caught in a stare. She’s jolted out of it by the sound of JENNIFER, approaching with a cup of tea. CAROL turns.
Thank you Jennifer, but I’m fine, really-
It‘ll calm your nerves. JENNIFER sets it down on a small end table, and places a on CAROL’s shoulder. Just then we hear the sound of a car coming up the drive.
They’re here. CAROL rises, gives her hair a quick pat and starts off to the door.

Just a moment, dear. CAROL stops, turns. JENNIFER walks over to where CAROL st her and adjusts her collar.  99 CAROL manages to maintain composure, then turn from JENNI and continues on to the door. EXT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON/EARLY EVENING. CONTINUOUS. CAROL runs to greet RINDY, who walks hand-in-hand with a MIDDLE AGED COUPLE, RINDY’S AUNT AND UNCLE. When she sees Mother, RINDY lets go of their hands and runs towards CAR They meet. CAROL kneels down and sweeps RINDY into her ar She hugs her tightly, holding on for dear life.

Oh baby... my baby girl... INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. AFTERNOON. DANNIE is over, helping THERESE repaint her apartment. THERESE is on a ladder, painting some molding near the ceiling and DANNIE is below. As the RADIO plays ("Lullaby Birdland” by Georges Shearing), DANNIE spots THERESE wipi sweat from her brow. They’ve clearly been at it a while.
I think it’s break time. Let me fetch some brews.

Sounds good. DANNIE goes to the kitchen to grab some beers and an open THERESE has been developing more photos - almost all of t pictures of CAROL from their trip. DANNIE can’t help but a look. He hears something behind him and turns. It’s THERESE.
These are seriously good. I mean, they really capture - whoever this is.
They're just practice. THERESE crosses the room and begins picking up the pictur tidying the area.

You really should put together a portfolio. Say the word, I’1l introduce you to my pal at the Times. There’s always a clerk job going.  100 THERESE shakes her head, takes the pictures into the othe room and s pulls open a drawer to stash them in. DANNIE (CONT’D) You went away with her, right?
Yes.
So what happened?
Ohh. Nothing. It’s - hard to...
(after a beat) Is it because I tried to kiss you that day? Because if it is, don’t even think about that, I mean, don’t be afraid of-

I’m not afraid. THERESE is stopped a moment by her own words, reminding h of another time and place. She looks back at him. THERESE (CONT’D) Let’s finish while we still have light, okay? DANNIE shrugs and they get back to work.

I still think you should put together that portfolio. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATE NIGHT. THERESE sits on her kitchen floor sorting photographs, a cigarette burning in an ashtray beside her. She’s busy placing them into neat piles. We see her older work - LANDSCAPES, STILL LIFE’S, ARCHITECTURAL DETAILS - and all newer work - PHOTOS OF KIDS PLAYING IN THE STREET, OLD WO DRAGGING SHOPPING CARTS, CITY FACES - virtually all of th depicting people. At the bottom of one pile she discovers picture of CAROL BUYING THE XMAS TREE. She considers it a moment before pulling it out of the stack. EXT. CENTRAL PARK. A FEW DAYS LATER. AFTERNOON. It’s a gray, rainy day at the park. Walkers with umbrella RICHARD has brought THERESE a box of her belongings.  101
Everything's there. (beat) My mother washed and ironed your blouses.
Thank her for me?
You can thank her yourself.
Richard...
What do you expect me to say? I mean... You never even wrote- THERESE looks away.
I tried, I just... I couldn’t find the words. She tries to touch his shoulder, he moves away from her.
Please don’t touch me. (he shakes his head). After what we had - after what you did... Throwing it all away.
What did we have?
Thanks, that’s...
No - tell me!
You tell me, Terry. Did you - did you love me even a little? They hold a look, but THERESE can’t hurt him like this. S turns away.
Please, please don’t hate me. I’m still... me. Still the same person I always was.  102

No. You’re not, alright? You’re someone else now. And I can’t. I can’t forgive you. (beat) So long, Terry. A beat, before RICHARD leaves. THERESE doesn’t move. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. DUSK. CAROL sits in the lantern seat off her stairway, looking at the night. From down below she hears the RADIO REPORT blaring on, announcing the death of Stalin. The radio is lowered and CAROL looks down. She sees Abby starting up the stairs with two cups of coffee. CAROL sta down to meet her.
Stay. Stay.
Don’t be silly. She takes her cup from ABBY and starts back up to her sea CAROL returns to where she was sitting and ABBY sits on t stairs below her. ABBY can read CAROL’s despondency from mile away.
I don’t know if I can do it, Abby. What more can I do? How many more - tomato aspic lunches... just to come home every night without her. To this!
And... Therese?
What about her?
Have you - heard anything?
Oh no. No. It’s been over a month since she tried to call. Nothing since then. I wish I... (but she stops, then): Have you? Heard anything?  103
From Therese? No. (beat) She must have started her job at the Times, though. That’s something.

I should have said: Therese. Wait. ABBY reaches out, puts a hand on CAROL’S foot. All at onc pair of headlights swing by, lighting up the windows, and they are jolted. CAROL turns and ABBY stands, startled. A look between them: is someone here? Is this trouble? And the headlights disappear.
Who the hell is turning around in my drive?
I should go.
You don’t have to-

-I do. ABBY squeezes CAROL’S hand - courage. And they start down stairs together. EXT. HUDSON RIVER PIER. NEW YORK. NIGHT. DANNIE and THERESE sit together on the pier, looking acro the river to New Jersey.
I’m glad you called... I never see you no more! Now that you’ve got the fancy job with the smooth hours. You punch out, I punch in.
It doesn’t feel fancy, hauling gallon jugs of developer all day. But I kind of love it, you know?

Sure. (beat) Hey - guess what happened to me? No? Can’t think of it? THERESE smiles, shakes her head.  104 DANNIE (CONT’D) I met a girl. Louise. She’s got green eyes, she’s a movie encyclopedia, and the most amazing thing? She thinks I’m boss.
(she’s pleased for DANNIE) Go figure.
(he’s pleased she’s Pleased) Yeah. (beat) If you want, we can all hang out some night. Go to a movie.
That sounds swell. I’d love to meet her. (pause) Did, uh - Have you seen Richard?

I seen him. (beat) Think he wanted to talk, maybe. But I, uh... I don’t know. I feel bad for him. But I don’t wanna get- He stops, glancing up at THERESE, then looking away. THERESE’s thoughts seem to harden and a brief darkness fa over her.
Use what feels right. Throw away the rest.
(laughs) Where’d that come from?
Something Carol once said to me.
(a beat, then: ) Did she... do that? To you? THERESE struggles for this...

I can’t - go. Back. To that place. Where you keep it all locked up... the sadness, shame... You let people down. You let yourself - down. So you cry and you... hide and think - things, constantly, crazy things, like... (MORE )

if you stare at the phone long enough or - take a train and just... lurk... it could all... return. (silence) And then one day the phone is just a phone. A train going to Jersey is just a train to Jersey. You stop - crying and hiding. And you know you’re able to use things and throw them away. The river looks like a swath of black cellophane.

INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. (APRIL 1953) THERESE sits on the edge of the bathtub next to the open window, taking in the air. She can hear the party in progress, people having a great time, but she’s not ready rejoin them. A couple of RAPID KNOCKS on the door.
Sorry. Just a second. THERESE gathers herself, gets up, opens the door. It’s GENEVIEVE. She wears her coat and scarf. THERESE (CONT’D) Oh. You’re leaving.
Just about. Will you miss me? THERESE doesn’t look away from GENEVIEVE this time. GENEV moves closer to THERESE, whispers in her ear.
Listen, Therese. There’s an intime gathering, quite exclusive you understand, later on. At my place. (beat) Quick. Show me your hand.
You a fortune teller?

I’m a fortune giver. GENEVIEVE takes THERESE’S hand, writes her address in ink onto THERESE’S palm. GENEVIEVE (CONT’D) So you don’t forget.  106 And GENEVIEVE'S off. THERESE watches her wind her way to door.

Through passing cars and car windows we suddenly see THER dressed for work in a smart dark suit, hurrying through t morning commuter CROWD towards the New York Times buildin Her style of hair and dress has taken on a sophistication maturity we can’t help but associate with CAROL. INT. TAXI. TIMES SQUARE. MORNING. CAROL, in the cab on her way to FRED HAYMES’S office, is looking distantly out the window when she suddenly spots The light changes and the taxi starts to move - THERESE flickers from view. CAROL looks back over her shoulder through reflections. INT. ELEVATOR/JERRY RIX LAW OFFICES. DAY. CAROL, turned away, inside the elevator. The doors open. turns to look a moment before heading out the door and do the hall. Gathered inside, HARGE, RIX, FRED HAYMES and a STENOGRAPH all turn and note her arrival.

head_text.subj: INT. JERRY RIX LAW OFFICES. DAY. MOMENTS LATER

text: Everyone is gathered around the conference table.
Well-(coughs)- we feel, given the seriousness of the charges and the incontestability of the evidence, my client has every reason to expect a compliant and favorable outcome.

Not so fast, Jerry. My client’s psychotherapist is perfectly satisfied with her recovery from... the events of the winter, asserting she’s more than capable of caring for her child. She’s had no further contact with Therese Belivet. (MORE )
A silence, 107

And we have sworn depositions from two Saddlebrook Institute psychiatrists clearly stating that, in their opinions, a series of events, precipitated by my client’s husband, drove her to suffer an emotional break, which resulted in this - described behavior.
(looks to his lawyer for help) That's absurd! - Are they serious-?
Alright, Fred - okay, if this is how you’re going to play this-
Furthermore, given the manner in which these tapes were obtained and recorded, we’re confident in their inadmissability-
Okay, okay. First off, I’d like to see these depositions. And second-
(interrupts him) Fred - please. Don’t - May I speak? as everybody in the room looks to CAROL.
I won’t deny the truth of what’s contained in those tapes.
(signals to the
This is off the record, honey.
Might as well be on the record. A pause as JERRY nods to the STENOGRAPHER to continue and CAROL pours herself a glass of water.
I wanted - I did want - to talk about... duty... sacrifice. That was what I-(beat)... But now that I’m here I don’t... I don’t know what I believe... Or what I even know... except that... (MORE )

I know I want to see my daughter - to hear her voice... Always. To be there when she’s- She stops, holding back tears, which she refuses to allow Gathering herself, she levels her eyes directly to Harge, makes her case directly to him.

Harge, I want you to be... happy. I didn’t give you that - I failed you - we both could have... given. More. (beat) But we gave each other Rindy, and that’s - the most - breathtaking, the most... generous... of gifts. (beat) So why are we spending so much time... coming up with ways to keep her from each other. (beat) What happened with Therese... I wanted. I won’t deny it or- HARGE looks down.

+. But I do regret, I - grieve... the mess we’re about to make... of our child’s life. We, Harge... we are both... responsible. Let’s... set it right. (beat) I want Harge to have... permanent custody- Amidst the sudden chaos HARGE’s eyes take hold of her and don’t let up.
Let’s take a break, folks and Fred - no, I think your resume when I’ve had a moment client has made it perfectl to confer with my- clear given her statement-

No, Fred. Let me have my say. Because - if you stop me... I won't... be able... to cope... CAROL stands, stepping away from the table, to regain her composure. Silence returns before she continues. CAROL (CONT’D) I’m no martyr. I have no clue... what’s best for me. But I do know... I feel, I feel it in my bones... what’s best for my daughter. She starts to turn and walk again, addressing HARGE.  109

(beat) I want visits with her, Harge. I don’t care if they’re supervised. But they need to be regular. (beat) There was a time... I would have locked myself away - done most anything... just to keep Rindy with me. But... what use am I to her... to us... living against... my own grain? Rindy deserves - joy. How do I give her that not knowing what it means... myself. She pours herself another glass of water.

That’s the deal. Take it or leave it. I can’t - I won’t negotiate. If you... leave it, we go to court and it gets ugly. We’re not ugly people, Harge. Feeling suddenly shaky she turns and starts out of the ro HARGE stands, staring at her as she goes, as FRED leaps t his feet and hurries after her, calling her name. EXT. COFFEE SHOP. SEVENTH AVENUE. DAY. Through reflections we see CAROL seated at a table, writi note. Beside her a pot of coffee and cigarette burning in ashtray. She signs it. Seals it inside an envelope, and begins gathering her things. INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPARTMENT. DAY. THERESE organizes black and white prints during a meeting photo editors, gathered around a large table. Smoke in th air. Through the glass a MESSENGER is seen speaking to a CLERK. The CLERK spots THERESE inside the room and brings the envelope.
Belivet. THERESE, looks up, and hurries over to the CLERK by the d He hands her the envelope.

Hand delivered. Swank. THERESE takes the envelope and returns to the table. Glan down, she recognizes CAROL'S handwriting.  110 INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPARTMENT. LATER. THERESE types labels at her cubicle. The open note sits beside her on her desk. She stops typing and looks over a the note. She picks it up and holds it for a moment befor crumpling it up and tossing it into a desk drawer. She returns to typing. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. NIGHT. CAROL is entering the hotel from the street entrance, removing her scarf and adjusting her hair. She makes her to the pay telephones and slips inside an empty booth. Th we see her dial a number and make a quick call. She hangs takes out her compact and powders her nose. She steps out the booth and stops. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. NIGHT. There, across the room, is THERESE being shown to a corne table, THERESE looking more grown-up and put together, THERESE thanking the MAITRE D’, THERESE sitting down... C takes a breath, then makes her way across the room. THERESE looks up and sees her.
I wasn’t sure you'd come. It’s nice of you to see me.
Don’t say that. CAROL settles in opposite THERESE, moving her coat aside.
Do you hate me, Therese?
No. How could I hate you?
I suppose you could. Didn’t you? For a while? THERESE looks down. She pours herself some tea.
Abby tells me you’re thriving. You've no idea how pleased I am for you. (beat) You look very fine, you know. As if you’ve suddenly blossomed. Is that what comes of getting away from me?  111
(answers quickly) No. She frowns, regretting answering so quickly, and looking down. When she looks up again, CAROL is staring at her, quite intently. THERESE (CONT’D) What?
Nothing. I was just thinking about that day. In the doll department.
I always wondered... Why did you come over to me?
Because you were the only girl not busy as hell. (beat) Disappointed? THERESE shakes her head no. CAROL smiles at the memory an lights a cigarette.

Harge and I are selling the house. I’ve taken an apartment. On Madison Avenue. And a job, believe it or not. I’m going to work for a furniture house on Fourth Avenue as a buyer. Some of my ancestors must have been carpenters. THERESE gives CAROL a little smile - a bit of thaw.
Have you seen Rindy?

(after a beat) Once or twice. At the lawyer’s office. She sat on my lap and we... (holding THERESE’S gaze): She's going to live with Harge. For now. It’s... the right thing. CAROL can’t quite cover the pain of this, but she tries.
Anyway, the apartment’s a nice big one - big enough for two. I was hoping you might like to come and live with me, but I guess you won't. (beat) Would you?  112 A held breath.
No. I don’t think so.
That's... your decision.
Yes. A silence.

I’m meeting some people from the furniture house at the Oak Room at nine. If you want to have dinner... if you change your mind... I think-- you'd like them. (beat) Well. That’s that. CAROL puts out her cigarette, stares at her cigarette lig on the table.
I love you. A silence. THERESE wants to say something, but can’t.
Therese? Is that you? And the moment is gone. THERESE looks up, turns towards t source of the greeting. It’s a smiling JACK TAFT, halfway across the room, near t bar.

What do you know! (starts over) I’m saying to myself, I know that girl. THERESE watches JACK make his way over to her. She gives CAROL a quick look - CAROL, staring down at the table, no knowing what to do, vulnerable... THERESE rises to greet JACK.
Jack.
Gee but it’s great to see you. It’s been, well, months.

Months.  113 CAROL lights a cigarette. THERESE glances at her, and the hold a look for a moment before THERESE speaks. THERESE (CONT’D) Jack, this is Carol Aird. JACK holds out his hand. CAROL shakes it.
Pleased to meet you.
Likewise. CAROL retreats back to her own thoughts, smokes.
Hey, Ted Gray’s meeting me here and a bunch of us are heading down to Phil’s party. You’re going aren’t you?
Well - yes. I just planned to get there a little...(looking to Carol)
You should go ahead.
You coming along?
No, no. (to THERESE) I should make a few calls before dinner, anyway. I should really run.
You sure?
Of course.
(to JACK) Well... it would be great to catch a ride. CAROL takes a step towards THERESE, but no more.
You two have a wonderful night. Nice meeting you, Jack.
Nice meeting you.  114 And she’s gone. THERESE doesn’t move, doesn’t turn around watch CAROL leave.

Alright, well let me go make sure the loaf is on his way. Back ina flash. And JACK’S off to the phone booth. A beat, before THERESE turns around. She scans the bar and beyond for CAROL, but she’s not there. THERESE walks to the lobby entrance - sh scans the lobby - but CAROL is well and truly gone - and only now hits THERESE that she let CAROL walk away. THERE turns and makes her way to the LADIES ROOM in a bit of a daze. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. LADIES ROOM. NIGHT. THERESE stands at the sink, water running. She can barely bring herself to look into the mirror. She splashes cold water on her face. INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. THERESE threads her way through PHIL’S GUESTS on her way the front door - it’s no easy task navigating, especially since no one seems to notice THERESE, or anything other t their own good time. When she finally reaches the door, THERESE takes a look back into the living room to see if she’s missed out on any good-byes. She spots DANNIE and LOUISE on the floor, knees-up to PHIL’S small black and w TV set, intently watching a film, oblivious to the noise around them. DANNIE jots notes every once in a while in h little notebook. All seems right here - for others at lea THERESE slips out the door. EXT. GREENWICH VILLAGE STREET. NIGHT. THERESE walks down a quaint, cobbled street. It’s a lovel night and there are various PEDESTRIANS out strolling. It seems to THERESE that she’s the only person who isn’t smiling, isn’t engaged with someone who’s actually beside on such a lovely evening. She looks at the palm of her ha checks the address, keeps walking. As she approaches the address, THERESE spots an ELDERLY COUPLE arm in arm, supporting each other, walking down the street towards he They look like they’ve been together for ever: the ELDERL WOMAN leaning in to her husband as they pass, the ELDERLY tipping his hat to THERESE. We HEAR SHARP LAUGHTER from a nearby apartment and THERES turns to see GENEVIEVE CANTRELL lean backwards out of a window. She holds a bottle of champagne which spills down into the street below.  115 GENEVIEVE gestures to someone inside, and ANOTHER WOMAN j GENEVIEVE at the window - the two begin to make out. THER watches their embrace for a moment; it’s tremendously sex GENEVIEVE pulls the WOMAN back into the apartment, and th window’s slammed shut behind them. The night is suddenly quiet. THERESE looks off in the direction the ELDERLY COU took. She starts walking, away from GENEVIEVE, toward something else. She begins to walk more quickly, and more quickly still, brushing past the world of strangers. INT. THE OAK ROOM. PLAZA HOTEL. NIGHT. THERESE, winded, enters the restaurant. A WAITER stops he
Do you have a reservation?
I’m looking for someone.

I'm sorry ma’am, I can’t seat you without- She moves away from the WAITER and scans the crowded room Nothing. Then, out of the corner of her eye, almost imperceptible at first, at a table towards the rear of th room, she sees a woman’s blonde head thrown back in laugh the woman seems to be encapsulated in or protected by a h of light and smoke. It’s CAROL, CAROL as THERESE has alwa seen her and as she will see her evermore: in SLOW MOTION like in a dream or a single, defining memory, substantial elusive. She moves towards her. CAROL raises a wine glass her lips and as she does, she turns slightly and spots THERESE. She is not startled. We see her face softening. THERESE continues to approach. CAROL watches with a smile burning in her eyes. THERESE has nearly arrived.
